As a combination, some of the earlier Akao artists worked in Echizen, I 
am at work and need a book here seriously (I have nothing else to do) 
but from memory, the early Akao stuff was from Echizen, then they moved 
to Kyoto after the second or third master..

I hope that is correct. I am running on gray matter here.

This is I believe Echizen Akao.
http://www.nihontokanjipages.com/personal/collection/akao.htm

Rich

Ron Hartmann wrote:
>
> Hi Elliott -
>
> I can see why you though Akasaka-something but if not that, look at 
> Akao group perhaps. I'm not coming up with any positive thoughts here, 
> just throwing out some idea. Doesn't look Kyo-sukashi to me. As for 
> Echizen...Echizen what? Echizen makes me think Kinai and that's not 
> Kinai work from what I can tell. Nice tsuba. The fukurin could be 
> added later so I guess one should think of it "without" that addition.
>
> Ron
> STL
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Elliott
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Monday, July 16, 2007 6:28 PM
> Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: It is very quiet here
>
> I am still here!
>
> After thumbing thru many books and web sites, I have decided to name
> my mysterious Tsuba (the one mounted on my Hiramasa) Echizen Sukashi.
> If you go to my album (Elliott's Album) and look at photo's 1 thru 7,
> tell me if you agree or what you think.
>
> I first thought Kyo-sukashi but Gordon said "I don't think so." Then
> I was leaning towards Akasaka but the Fukurin was telling me "no". So
> I threw my hands up and pondered other stuff.
>
> It wasn't until I was 'talking' to Andy Quirt when I ask him and he
> suggested Echizen. I hadn't thought of that but I went to searching
> and maybe............it is!
>
> What do you think?
>
> Elliott
